title: How to Determine Relative Humidity: Formulas & More

steps.title: Find the air temperature and dew-point temperature in Celsius.
steps.content: Find the air temperature and dew-point temperature in Celsius. If your temperature isn’t in Celcius already, convert it with the formula C = 5 9 ∗ ( F − 32 ) {\displaystyle C={\frac {5}{9}}*(F-32)} , where ( C ) {\displaystyle (C)} = Celsius temperature and ( F ) {\displaystyle (F)} = Fahrenheit temperature. [2] X Research source You can find the dew-point by checking the weather page of your local newspaper or a website that publishes weather information for your local area, such as weather.gov. [3] X Research source For example, if the temperature is 100°F, you would first subtract 32 from 100, which gives you 68. Then, you would multiply 68 by 5/9, which gives a temperature of 37.778°C. You can also use online temperature converters to simplify this step.

steps.title: Calculate the saturated vapor pressure with a formula.
steps.content: Calculate the saturated vapor pressure with a formula. After converting the air temperature to Celsius, use this formula to calculate the saturated vapor pressure: 6.11 x 10^(7.5 x air temperature) / (237.3 + air temperature) . [4] X Research source

steps.title: Find the actual vapor pressure with the same formula.
steps.content: Find the actual vapor pressure with the same formula. You can use the same formula to find the actual vapor pressure. Just substitute the dew point for the air temperature in the formula. [5] X Research source Actual vapor pressure = 6.11 x 10^(7.5 x dew point) / (237.3 + dew point)

steps.title: Divide the actual vapor pressure by the saturation pressure.
steps.content: Divide the actual vapor pressure by the saturation pressure. Once you’ve divided your values, multiply them by 100 to get a percentage: Relative humidity = actual vapor pressure / saturation vapor pressure. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Use an online relative humidity calculator for speed and convenience.
steps.content: Use an online relative humidity calculator for speed and convenience. If math is not your forte, there are several online calculators you can use to calculate relative humidity. Just punch in the temperature and dew point, and you can find out what the relative humidity is in a fraction of a second. [7] X Research source You can use the National Weather Service’s relative humidity calculator here .

steps.title: Buy two identical plastic student thermometers.
steps.content: Buy two identical plastic student thermometers. A plastic student thermometer is a cheap tube thermometer affixed on a white plastic backing. They are typically around 2 inches (5.1 cm) wide and 6 inches (15 cm) long and have a hole through the top of the plastic backing and a bulb at the bottom of the tube. The thermometers should also be mercury-free. You should be able to find plastic student thermometers at most office supply stores and some major retailers.

steps.title: Put a washer and thermometer onto a 2 in (5.1 cm) metal screw.
steps.content: Put a washer and thermometer onto a 2 in (5.1 cm) metal screw. First, slide the washer onto the screw. Then put the screw through the hole of one of your two thermometers. It doesn’t matter which thermometer you first put on the screw.

steps.title: Put a plastic spacer, thermometer, and washer onto the same screw.
steps.content: Put a plastic spacer, thermometer, and washer onto the same screw. After the washer and thermometer are on the screw, cut a 0.5 in (1.3 cm) section of a plastic straw, and slide it on. Then add the other thermometer and another washer. [8] X Research source You can use another type of plastic spacer if it’s about the same size.

steps.title: Tighten the screw into a 6 in (15 cm) long wooden dowel.
steps.content: Tighten the screw into a 6 in (15 cm) long wooden dowel. Use a screwdriver to fix the screw into the dowel. Tighten the screw just enough so that it is secure. Be sure to leave plenty of room for the two thermometers to swing. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap a piece of cloth around the bulb of one of the thermometers.
steps.content: Wrap a piece of cloth around the bulb of one of the thermometers. Use enough cloth to fully cover the bulb (about 2 inches (5.1 cm)), then secure it with a piece of string or rubber band. This will be your “wet-bulb” thermometer. [10] X Research source For example, a section of a hollow shoelace, slit down the middle to create a single layer of cloth, works well. The thermometer without the cloth will be your dry-bulb thermometer.

steps.title: Dip the bottom of the wet-bulb thermometer in a cup of water.
steps.content: Dip the bottom of the wet-bulb thermometer in a cup of water. Allow the cloth to get completely soaked, then take it out and gently squeeze out the excess water. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Swing the thermometers for five minutes.
steps.content: Swing the thermometers for five minutes. Hold the dowel out from your body and spin it so that the two thermometers whirl around the screw. As you swing the thermometers, water evaporates from the wet cloth you attached to your wet-bulb thermometer. This evaporation cools the bulb and lowers the temperature recorded on the wet-bulb thermometer. [12] X Research source The amount of water that will evaporate from your psychrometer depends on how much water the atmosphere around it can hold. In a very humid environment, there’s not as much space for the water to evaporate into , so your cloth will be wetter at the end of the experiment. More evaporation happens when the air is dry because dry air has a higher capacity than moist air to absorb additional moisture. Wear safety glasses during this step.

steps.title: Subtract the wet-bulb temperature from the dry-bulb temperature.
steps.content: Subtract the wet-bulb temperature from the dry-bulb temperature. Record the temperatures from the two thermometers, starting with the wet-bulb. The wet-bulb temperature should be lower than the dry bulb. [13] X Research source The drier the air, the lower the wet-bulb temperature will be relative to the dry-bulb temperature.

steps.title: Consult a relative humidity chart or table.
steps.content: Consult a relative humidity chart or table. From these readings, you can figure out the relative humidity. Just find where the dry-bulb temperature and the difference between the wet- and dry-bulb readings intersect on the chart. You can also find a decent relative humidity chart here . While this method will not give you a 100% accurate reading, it will give you an approximate measurement of how much water vapor there is in the air.

steps.title: Finding absolute humidity from relative humidity
steps.content: Finding absolute humidity from relative humidity If you want to reverse the equation, multiply the relative humidity by the actual vapor pressure to get saturation vapor pressure, which is absolute humidity. [14] X Research source Absolute humidity = relative humidity * actual vapor pressure

steps.title: Finding how much water is in the air
steps.content: Finding how much water is in the air If you have the temperature, relative humidity percentage, and saturation rate, you can find out the mass of water in the air. [15] X Research source The saturation rate is how many grams of water air can hold at a certain temperature per kilogram. Multiply the saturation rate at the temperature by the humidity percentage. Use a table to find the saturation rate for your temperature.

steps.title: Take readings from the middle of the room.
steps.content: Take readings from the middle of the room. Turn on your hygrometer if it’s digital, then hold it about 1.5 metres (4.9 ft) off the ground in the middle of a room. [16] X Research source Since it has the most airflow, you’ll get the best reading from the very center. If you can, close all the doors and windows before taking a reading.

steps.title: Hold the device as far from your body as possible.
steps.content: Hold the device as far from your body as possible. When you breathe out, the air you’re expelling can be up to 95% relative humidity. [17] X Trustworthy Source Library of Congress Official library of the U.S. and main research institution for Congress and the American public Go to source To get the most accurate results, hold the hygrometer away from your body with your arm straight out.

steps.title: Wait 1-2 minutes before taking your reading.
steps.content: Wait 1-2 minutes before taking your reading. If your hygrometer settles on a percentage before 2 minutes are up, use that number. [18] X Research source To speed up the process, move the hygrometer slowly back and forth, about 2 times per second.
